description: Silver dataset for evaluating discovery question quality - strength-first philosophy

samples.description: Senior engineer applying to staff role - bridge mentoring to leadership
expected_question_qualities: Shows how mentoring IS leadership (bridge-building)
Frames microservices work as system design experience they already have
Helps them see cross-team impact they may not have highlighted
Makes them feel MORE qualified than they thought
gold_question_examples: Mentoring juniors at TechCorp is exactly the multiplier effect Staff roles need - when did teaching someone unlock something for your own understanding?
Building microservices means you've already done system design - what tradeoff did you make that you're secretly proud of, even if it seemed routine?
3 years at TechCorp means you've seen patterns others miss - when did your knowledge of the codebase save the team hours of debugging?
anti_patterns: You don't have formal leadership experience - tell me about any leadership you might have
Tell me about your cross-team collaboration experience
What system design ownership have you had?

samples.description: Product manager pivoting to engineering - bridge technical PM work to coding
expected_question_qualities: Shows how PM data work IS engineering-adjacent (bridge-building)
Frames their SQL/analysis as technical foundation they already have
Surfaces hidden coding they did but didn't highlight
Makes career change feel like natural progression, not a leap
gold_question_examples: Growing DAU 3x at StartupXYZ required data work - you probably wrote SQL queries that engineers later productionized. What analysis of yours became a feature?
Technical PMs often end up debugging with engineers - at StartupXYZ, did you ever find yourself in the code trying to understand why something wasn't working?
Leading cross-functional teams means you've translated between engineering and business - that's half of API design. When did you shape how a feature was built?
anti_patterns: You don't have engineering experience - do you have any coding experience?
Why do you want to switch to engineering?
What production code have you written?

samples.description: Junior developer applying to mid-level - bridge agency variety to performance expertise
expected_question_qualities: Shows agency variety IS the adaptability mid-level roles need (bridge-building)
Reframes 'fixing bugs' as performance debugging they've already done
Helps them see client work as technical decision-making
Makes 2 years of dense agency work feel like equivalent experience
gold_question_examples: 2 years at an agency means you've touched more codebases than most 5-year engineers - when did jumping into unfamiliar code stop feeling scary?
Fixing bugs at AgencyWeb is basically performance debugging - what's a bug that made you feel like a detective when you finally cracked it?
Client projects force fast technical decisions - at AgencyWeb, when did you push back on a client request because you saw a better way?
anti_patterns: You only have 2 years of experience - tell me about performance optimization you might have done
Describe your experience level compared to the requirements
What technical leadership have you had as a junior?

samples.description: Backend engineer applying to full-stack - bridge API work to full-stack thinking
expected_question_qualities: Shows API design IS half of full-stack (bridge-building)
Surfaces frontend work they did but didn't list
Reframes backend expertise as full-product thinking they already have
Makes full-stack feel like a natural extension, not a gap
gold_question_examples: Building REST APIs at DataCorp means you already think about how consumers use your work - that's half of full-stack. Did you ever see frontend struggling with your design?
5 years of backend work means you've probably built admin panels or internal tools - any of those have UIs you built yourself?
Database optimization requires understanding the full request path - when did you trace a slow query all the way to the user experience?
anti_patterns: You don't have frontend experience - have you ever used React?
What full-stack projects have you worked on?
Do you have any JavaScript experience?

samples.description: Bootcamp grad with career change - bridge nursing to tech skills
expected_question_qualities: Shows nursing skills ARE tech skills (bridge-building)
Frames emergency response as incident debugging they already know
Healthcare domain is their ADVANTAGE, not something to overcome
Makes career change feel like bringing superpowers, not filling gaps
gold_question_examples: Managing patient handoffs in a hospital is basically incident response in tech - what made the difference between a smooth handoff and a dangerous one?
6 years of nursing means you've debugged symptoms to find root causes - when did your diagnosis prove everyone else wrong?
Healthcare at HealthTech is your superpower - what's something about patient workflows that engineers always get wrong?
anti_patterns: You don't have professional dev experience - why should we consider you?
Why are you switching careers from nursing?
How do you compare to candidates with CS degrees?
